title: Texts about to go out giving millions of Aussies cash boost
text:
Millions of Australians are still facing a weeks-long wait ﻿to see promised student debt relief kick in after the new legislation took effect in late September.

The laws fulfil a key election pledge to cut student debt by 20 per cent for all Australians.

Today, it's been revealed when people can expect to start seeing that tangible relief.

NRL GRAND FINAL LIVE: Slater backs Mam's bench role to work wonders ﻿

Millions of Australians are expecting a debt reduction. (iStock)

The tax office will begin applying the cut from mid-November, and anticipates that 50 per cent of people with a student debt will see the cut kick in by the end of that month.

Almost everybody else will see the cut applied to their balance by mid-December.

"Soon millions of Australians with student debt will get a text message from the ATO when the 20 per cent cut to their debt has been processed, a cut we promised during the election and have delivered," Assistant Treasurer Daniel Mulino said.

READ MORE: Aussies around the country are welcoming hundreds of snakes into their homes ﻿

The average ex-student will see more than $5000 wiped from their debt. (Getty Images/iStockphoto)

"This is helping millions of students and graduates across the country who have invested in their education with the next step in their lives."

Regardless of when it kicks in, the reduction will be backdated to what a person's debt balance was on June 1, before indexation.

People will be notified by text message or email when the cut happens and will be able to check their accounts to see their new lower balance.

For someone with the average debt of $27,600, this will see $5520 wiped.

No action from debtors is required to ensure the cut is applied - it will happen automatically.﻿

"We promised we would cut your student debt by 20 per cent and we are delivering," Education Minister Jason Clare said.

"This is a big deal for 3 million Australians.

"This cut is already locked in to people's balances at 1 June but soon they will be able to see it and feel it.

"Just out of uni, just getting started, this is taking a weight off their back."

title: Major bank gives update no one wants to hear
text:
ANZ has become the third of the big four banks to strike down predictions of another cut to interest rates in 2025.

The bank now expects the next cut to come in February 2026, in a blow for mortgage-holders.

In the past eight days, three of the major banks have changed their economic forecasts on the cash rate, shifting the next anticipated RBA cut from November to next year.

ANZ is now not predicting another rate cut before 2026. (NilsBV/iStock)

ANZ and Commonwealth both expect the cut to come in February, while the NAB anticipates a wait until May.

All three banks expect just one more cut in the cycle.

Westpac is still forecasting cuts in November, February, and May, but its economics team said a November cut was "far from assured".﻿

READ MORE: Texts about to go out giving millions of Aussies cash boost ﻿

The growing uncertainty around a further cut this year has prompted a warning to borrowers to be on the lookout for a competitive r﻿ate.

"Households waiting for the RBA to swoop in with a cut could be waiting a while. If you want to get ahead on your mortgage, take matters into your own hands by shopping around for a sharper rate," Canstar data insights director Sally Tindall said.

"Owner-occupiers paying down their debt might be able to pick up a deal under 5.25 per cent, while investors can aim for under 5.5 per cent, particularly if they're willing to pay both principal and interest. If you're paying significantly more, it's time to take action."

She said cashback deals, while not as "abundant" as they were at their 2023 peak, were still available from multiple lenders.

And frequent flyer points were also being offered with loans from multiple banks.

"However, with any upfront sweetener, borrowers should remember, free flights and cold hard cash might sound appealing, but the real savings typically come from securing a low interest rate, particularly on larger loans and especially if you're unlikely to refinance regularly," Tindall said.

title: The woman who is set to be Japan's next leader
text:
In a country that ranks poorly internationally for gender equality, the new president of Japan's long-governing Liberal Democrats, and likely next prime minister, is an ultra-conservative star of a male-dominated party that critics call an obstacle to women's advancement.

Sanae Takaichi, 64, admires former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and is a proponent of former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's conservative vision for Japan.

Takaichi is the first female president of Japan's predominantly male ruling party that has dominated Japan's postwar politics almost without interruption.

Sanae Takaichi, the newly-elected leader of Japan's ruling party, the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP). (AP)

She hardly touched on gender issues during the campaign, but on Saturday, as she tried out the party president's chair and posed for a photo as is customary for the newly elected leader, Takaichi said: "Now that the LDP has its first female president, its scenery will change a little."

First elected to parliament from her hometown of Nara in 1993, she has served in key party and government posts, including minister of economic security, internal affairs and gender equality.

Female lawmakers in the conservative Liberal Democratic Party who were given limited ministerial posts have often been shunned as soon as they spoke up about diversity and gender equality. Takaichi has stuck with old-fashioned views favoured by male party heavyweights.

Takaichi celebrates with Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba after winning the LDP leadership election. (Getty)

Takaichi also admits she is a workaholic who would rather study at home instead of socialising. After unsuccessfully running for party presidency twice in the past, she made efforts to be more sociable to build connections as advised, she said.

But on Saturday, as she called for an all-out effort to rebuild the party and regain public support, she asked all party lawmakers to "work like a horse." Then she added, "I will abandon the word 'work-life balance.' I will work, work, work and work."

The "work-life balance" quickly trended on social media, triggering mixed reactions – support for her enthusiasm and concern about her work ethic.

Japan's politics are largely male-dominated. (AP)

Women comprise only about 15 per cent of Japan's lower house, the more powerful of the two parliamentary chambers. Only two of Japan's 47 prefectural governors are women.

A drummer in a heavy-metal band and a motorbike rider as a student, Takaichi has called for a stronger military, more fiscal spending for growth, promotion of nuclear fusion, cybersecurity and tougher policies on immigration.

She vowed to drastically increase female ministers in her government. But experts say she might actually set back women's advancement because as leader she would have to show loyalty to influential male heavyweights. If not, she risks a short-lived leadership.

Takaichi has backed financial support for women's health and fertility treatment as part of the LDP policy of having women serve in their traditional roles of being good mothers and wives. But she also recently acknowledged her struggles with menopausal symptoms and stressed the need to educate men about female health to help women at school and work.

Takaichi supports the imperial family's male-only succession, opposes same-sex marriage and a revision to the 19th-century civil law that would allow separate surnames for married couples so that women don't get pressured into abandoning theirs.

She is a wartime history revisionist and China hawk. She regularly visits Yasukuni Shrine, which Japan's neighbours consider a symbol of militarism, though she has declined to say what she would do as prime minister.

Political watchers say her revisionist views of Japan's wartime history may complicate ties with Beijing and Seoul.

Her hawkish stance is also a worry for the LDP's longtime partnership with Komeito, a Buddhist-backed moderate party. While she has said the current coalition is crucial for her party, she says she is open to working with far-right groups.

title: What will and won't be open on the public holiday
text:
Millions of Australians will have some time off this weekend as they celebrate one of two public holidays.

For Aussies in South Australia, New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory, it will be their Labour Day.

Queensland residents will have a public holiday on the same day to commemorate the King's Birthday.

So what will be the trading hours for Australia's biggest retailers this long weekend?

Here's a quick state-by-state guide. ﻿

Coles

Stores across NSW, ACT and QLD will be open as normal.

﻿In SA, all stores will be closed except for﻿ Port Lincoln, Port Pirie, Berri, Port Augusta, Mount Barker, Adelaide Rundle Place, Whyalla, Murray Bridge Green, Mount Gambier and Victor Harbor.

Full trading hours can be found on their website .

Aldi

Store hours will vary for different stores and states.

Full trading hours for each store can be found on their website﻿

READ MORE: When October long weekend double demerits apply for motorists

Aldi recommends that customers check their local stores trading hours on their website (Nine)

Woolworths

All stores except for some in South Australia and the Northern Territory will be open.

﻿Full trading hours can be found on their website .

Liquorland

Stores in states celebrating the public holidays will trade with reduced trading hours.﻿

In Queensland,﻿ some stores will be closed for the public holiday.

Full trading hours can be found on their website .

READ MORE: How to maximise public holidays and make the most of your annual leave in 2025

Some stores in Queensland will be closed for the public holiday. (Jon W / Event Photos Australia)

Dan Murphy's and BWS

﻿Dan Murphy's stores nationwide will mostly open from 10am to 7pm.

BWS stores will mostly open from 9am and close between 7pm and 8pm.

Full trading hours can be found on their website﻿ .

Bunnings﻿

All Bunnings stores will be open on the October long weekend.

Most stores in states where there is a public holiday will be open from 7am to 7pm.﻿

﻿Shoppers are advised to use the Bunnings website or app to check their local store's trading hours, as opening times will vary.

Bunnings stores statewide will remain open on the public holidays. (Supplied)

title: Tiny endangered tropical sea turtle found far from home in WA
text:
How did a tropical reptile, only slightly bigger than a dinner plate, end up on Western Australia's south coast hundreds of kilometres from home?

That's what wildlife carers have asked after a juvenile green turtle, in poor condition, washed up on a beach in Esperance, 800 kilometres south-east of Perth, last week.

The juvenile sea turtle was found in poor condition at Wylie Bay, a popular beach just east of Esperance. (Supplied: Lori-Ann Shibish)

The unlikely traveller, usually found in the warm waters along the north-west of WA, had a large gash above its front flipper, was sluggish and had what appeared to be an eye infection.

Rush to help

The injured animal was quickly transferred to the nearby Esperance Wildlife Hospital by a young family who found it washed ashore at Wylie Bay, about 10km east of town.

Hospital co-founder Lori-Ann Shibish said the initial treatment over several days was done alongside Dr Alex Hockton under the advice of Perth Zoo veterinary staff.

Lori-Ann Shibish says she was surprised a tropical sea turtle was found this far south. (ABC Esperance: Andrew Williams)

"It had a huge gash on the top of its right flipper. It was cut right open and you could see the muscle," she said.

"And the last issue it had was when we put it in the water, it was floating, so it could not dive, which indicated it somehow had air trapped in its shell."

Ms Shibish said a plan was then hatched to transport the turtle to Perth for more specialist care, with a call put out on social media for any potential volunteers to make the drive.

Jade Sing agreed to help and was dubbed the "turtle taxi".

Jade Sing volunteered to transport the injured turtle 800km to Perth. (Supplied: Lori-Ann Shibish)

It takes a village

WA Wildlife Hospital chief executive Dean Huxley said the turtle was in poor condition on arrival.

"When it came to us, it was very lethargic and quite weak," he said.

In addition to the large wound on its front flipper, it appeared to have had a run-in with a predator in the past.

The green turtle had a large gash across one of its front flippers. (Supplied: WA Wildlife Hospital)

"Its back flippers had sustained an old injury … so at some point it's been attacked, potentially by a shark," Mr Huxley said.

"Both of its back flippers were pretty much bitten in half, so it really only has the use of its two front flippers."

Fortunately, the turtle is on the road to recovery, and Mr Huxley said it could not have been done without help from the community.

Dean Huxley says saving the turtle would not have been possible without the community coming together. (Supplied: WA Wildlife Hospital)

"This is a really good example of the whole community working together. There were a lot of different groups involved in this turtle's rescue," he said.

"It just goes to show that no one group can do all this, and it really does take a village."

Mr Huxley said the turtle would remain under the hospital's care until it fully recovered and would then be transported back to its natural habitat.

The WA Wildlife Hospital has cared for the young turtle since it arrived in Perth. (Supplied: WA Wildlife Hospital)

"It's going to have to be flown back up north so that it can be released back into its normal area," he said.

"Probably somewhere near Broome or Port Hedland."

Not the first vagrant

The green turtle is not the first "vagrant" to have been found in the waters near Esperance in the last few years.

In January 2023, a westland petrel was found at Wylie Bay, the first time the species had ever been recorded in WA.

The green turtle was found by a young family at Wylie Bay, just east of Esperance. (ABC Esperance: Andrew Williams)

Then, just months later, three Fiordland crested penguins, one of the world's rarest species of penguin, were found along the Esperance coastline.

The penguins are normally found along the south-western tip of New Zealand's South Island, almost 4,000km away.

In 2023, Lori-Ann Shibish helped nurse three Fiordland crested penguins back to health. (ABC Esperance: Emily Smith)

"A lot of these animals show up and they're very malnourished and in poor physical condition," Ms Shibish said.

"There is something happening in the lives of these animals which is causing them to move further away from their normal habitats.

" We're just not sure what that is. "

Uncommon but not unheard of

Murdoch University researcher Jenna Hounslow is a movement ecologist who studies where animals move and why.

She said while the juvenile green turtles' appearance in the state's south coast waters was not the norm, it was not unheard of.

Jenna Hounslow says green turtles rarely travel further south than Shark Bay. (Supplied: Jenna Hounslow)

"This is definitely outside of their southerly range limit [Shark Bay]," Dr Hounslow said.

"Any further south and the water would be getting a bit cold for them."

She said there could be many reasons as to why the reptile ranged so far south.

"It may have been caught on the warm water Leeuwin current, which runs north to south down the west coast," she said.

"And it could also be related to the marine heatwave that WA has been experiencing since this time last year."

title: Minimise weeknight cooking with these easy, big-batch recipes
text:
It's always reassuring to have a few meals stashed in the fridge or freezer.

Cut down on weeknight cooking with these options that feed between six and eight people.

Alternating between pasta sheets and thinly sliced zucchini increases the veggie content of this comforting dish. (ABC Everyday: Tim Grey)

Don't have all afternoon to make a lasagne? Same. This version uses layers of fresh zucchini and frozen peas. The only cooking you'll need to do is making a quick crème fraîche sauce with leeks.

Cooking tips: Save time by using pre-shredded cheese.

This one-tray chicken tandoori bake delivers on flavour and saves on time and dishes. (ABC TV: Wesley Mitton)

This recipe is popular for a reason. Six chicken thighs bake on top of biryani-inspired rice that's spiced and soaks up the flavour of both the chicken thighs and stock as they cook.

Cooking tips: The prep time is a fast 15 minutes but be sure to factor in an hour for the chicken to marinate.

This pea and ham soup is a fresh and bright take on a classic winter meal in time for spring. (ABC News: Eve Wilson)

Frozen peas replace split peas in this vibrant take on a classic winter dish. While this dish has a long cook time, you'll be rewarded with a meal that feeds between 6-8.

Cooking tips: This soup freezes well, but the ham will become saltier when frozen then defrosted, so season with this in mind if freezing.

The ingredients I've used here are purposefully basic and pantry-friendly. (ABC News: Hetty Lui McKinnon)

Bolognese is a favourite in many homes and this vegetarian version uses pantry staples, hopefully saving you a trip to the shops and some money, too.

Cooking tips: Option to add cream to the bolognese before serving. Swap the tomato paste for a spice paste like harissa or gochujang if you enjoy a bit of heat.

Little effort, huge reward. This simple recipe leaves you with two creamy mushroom tarts to share, or keep. (ABC Everyday: Tim Grey)

Make two mushroom and cheese tarts in 35 minutes using store-bought puff pastry. Savoury tarts can be served at room temperature or hot alongside a salad.

Cooking tips: There's only 15 minutes prep in this recipe. The ingredients are sliced and assembled before it's time to bake.

title: Greens leader 'doesn't know very much' about wind farm opposed by colleagues
text:
Greens leader Larissa Waters has avoided stating a position on the Robbins Island wind farm, a renewables project opposed by two of her parliamentary colleagues.

The Tasmanian project, a 100-turbine facility that would be Tasmania's largest, is fervently opposed by the minor party's two Tasmanian senators, Nick McKim and Peter Whish-Wilson, on the grounds it threatens several endangered species.

Senator Waters told the ABC's Insiders she was not familiar enough with the high-profile project to state a position but that renewables projects should not unduly threaten biodiversity.

Robbins Island wind farm approved after years of delays Photo shows Robbins Island, Tasmania A 100-turbine wind farm, the largest in Tasmania, will be built on Robbins Island in north-west Tasmania following seven delays to the decision, and multiple court appeals.

"I don't know very much about that … we will be looking at that closely," she said.

"I accept it has to be in the right place and if this one isn't, let's look at somewhere else to put it…

"We are going to need to balance the need for large-scale and small-scale renewable energy against the needs of biodiversity and I don't think it's beyond our ability."

Environment Minister Murray Watt granted conditional approval to the Robbins Island wind farm in August, imposing 88 requirements on the operator to safeguard species including the critically endangered orange-bellied parrot and the endangered Tasmanian devil and Tasmanian wedge-tailed eagle.

Senators McKim and Whish-Wilson released a joint statement condemning that decision, saying it was "the worst possible place anyone could build a wind farm".

"The approval of this obviously inappropriate project will only serve to undermine community confidence in our already flailing rollout of renewable energy," Senator Whish-Wilson said.

"Of course we need more renewable energy projects, but this is the wrong project in the wrong place," Senator McKim said.

Veteran former Greens leader Bob Brown, a Tasmanian, has also campaigned against the farm through his foundation.

Orange-bellied parrots are critically endangered. (Supplied: Orange-bellied Parrot Program)

'No-go zones' should be in environmental reforms

Senator Waters said the renewables rollout should be accelerated with long-awaited reforms to environmental laws.

Labor tried to pass those reforms in the last term, balancing the concerns of environmental groups and businesses who say major projects take too long to obtain a "yes" or "no".

Efforts have been renewed under Murray Watt and appear closer to success, but the government has not detailed any changes to the proposal that failed to pass in the last parliament.

The Greens want the environment minister to be required by law to consider the impacts of major infrastructure projects on climate change, viewing renewables projects more favourably and effectively preventing new fossil fuel projects.

"That will continue to be a core demand of ours. You can't have environmental laws that don't protect the environment or think about the climate impacts of what we do," she said.

Senator Waters said the government should end native forest logging and should ensure its environmental laws designate "no-go zones" where applications are not considered, citing the Bowen Basin.

The Greens leader did not endorse the Climate Change Authority's advice that wind power should quadruple by 2035 in alignment with its recommended emissions reduction goal of 62 to 70 per cent on 2005 levels.

"I support quadrupling renewable energy. I have an open mind as to what particular technology will be the most efficient," she said, adding Labor's climate target was "pathetic" and "will imperil us all".

title: Town behind Babe's 'storybook world' celebrates film's 30th anniversary
text:
Three decades ago, Australian filmmaker George Miller made an unlikely career move when he set out to produce a film about a talking piglet trained by a border collie to become a sheep-herding star.

With a growing filmography, including the original Mad Max movies, he set out to find the perfect location to create the now cherished children's classic, Babe.

"We were looking for a place that was close enough to infrastructure, like a town where we could stay, not too far from Sydney," Miller said.

He chose the tiny town of Robertson, known as the "green heart" of the NSW Southern Highlands, south-west of Wollongong.

"We wanted to create a storybook world," Miller said.

Babe, filmed in the Southern Highlands, has a "storybook world" look and feel. (Supplied: Universal Pictures)

"There were no gum trees, so it didn't look specifically Australian … and the earth was quite sculptured."

But according to the town's business chamber, an agreement with production company Universal Studios meant Robertson could not promote itself as the location where the film was shot.

"The population was a lot smaller back then, and I think [the film crew] used every resource that they could," Robertson Business Chamber president Jennifer Macquarie said.

Miller's production company lifted the restriction earlier this year, allowing the town to celebrate and claim its status as the home of Babe.

Big potato turned pig

Similar to the town featured in the film, Robertson has been transformed into a country fair this weekend, with a petting zoo and cake stall, to mark 30 years since Babe was released.

The biggest attraction at Sunday's event will be the town's famous Big Potato, which was given a pig-pink makeover by Wollongong street artist Samuel Hall in March.

Loading...

"It was a bit of a strange commission because we weren't sure how the town would react," Mr Hall said.

"But it's been overwhelmingly positive … with some suggesting the potato should stay a pig."

Mr Hall said he used the Big Potato's odd shape to depict a pig lying in the grass alongside some of his favourite characters like Ferdinand the duck.

"It was a challenge and more of a gift to the town," he said.

Samuel Hall is the artist behind the Big Potato's transformation into Babe the pig. (ABC Illawarra: Mikayla McGuirk-Scolaro)

Local farm recruited for film

Robertson potato farmer Roden Mauger was a teenager when Miller wandered into the local real estate agency looking for the most suitable property to film Babe.

"Dad came home and said the guy who made the 'Crazy Max' (aka Mad Max) films wants to use our property," he said.

The family home became Arthur Hoggett's farm in the movie.

The Mauger family's farm was an idyllic location for the film's producers. (Supplied: John Cox)

"[The crew] were there for 18 months, so we got to know a lot of the people," Mr Mauger said.

"I fertilised some of the paddocks, we slashed and we even coloured some of the paddocks so they looked like Fallow Fields.

"The film set didn't affect us … it was actually a bonus."

Roden Mauger (left) at the official unveiling of the artistic dedication earlier this year. (ABC Illawarra: Mikayla McGuirk-Scolaro)

New technology makes animals talk

Babe stole the hearts and minds of its audience with not just its cute characters, but also its use of cutting-edge visual effects.

John Cox, who won an Academy Award for Best Visual Effects for Babe in 1996, was one of the masterminds behind the animation.

Although SGI digital dispensation had only recently been developed, Mr Cox said it was critical in replacing the front of an animal's face to make them talk.

Babe was made using a mix of props, real animals and digital animation. (Supplied: John Cox)

"The attention to the detail was very important," he said

"There was a different department for each animal … and a breeding program so we can use pigs of a specific size.

"Sheep were given a six-to-seven-month regrowth period so the fleece we had on the robot sheep was the same."

The film went on to rake in over $351 million at the box office.

title: Hepatitis B cases are rising in the NT, but experts say it's a positive sign
text:
Yolŋu elder and Aboriginal health worker George Gurruwiwi remembers the devastating impact of hepatitis B in his community of Galiwin'ku 20 years ago.

He recalls many deaths from chronic hepatitis B in the Elcho Island community, and constantly going to sorry business, or funerals.

"Especially here, Elcho, and other parts of the community, it's avoidable death, a lot of death out here," he said.

"We [were] doing ceremony after ceremony."

George Gurruwiwi is part of a program working to reduce hepatitis B across the NT. (Supplied)

At first glance, the latest hepatitis B data for the Northern Territory appears to paint a grim picture.

The figures provided by NT Health, which only cover the first six months of each year, show diagnoses almost tripled between 2022 and 2024.

But rather than being a cause for concern, healthcare workers say it's actually a sign the Northern Territory is leading the nation in terms of care for the viral infection.

George Gurruwiwi says prevention efforts are working in his home community of Galiwin'ku. (Supplied)

Mr Gurruwiwi says he has seen the change firsthand, having noticed fewer hepatitis B deaths in his community in recent years.

Since 2019, he has been a key partner with NT hepatitis B prevention program HEP B PAST, working to improve access to testing and treatment in Arnhem Land as both a community liaison and researcher.

"I mentor through a cultural perspective, through kinship," he said.

"The difference is people understand."

Falling morality rates

Seventy per cent of people who have hepatitis B in the Northern Territory are Indigenous, according to data from the World Health Organization (WHO) Collaborating Centre for Viral Hepatitis.

Landmark hepatitis study tracks ancient human movements Photo shows footprints in the desert In what they believe is an Australian first, researchers have used a unique strain of hepatitis B virus to deduce ancient human population movements into Australia.

The territory is also home to an aggressive strain of hepatitis B called C4, which has only ever been diagnosed in Aboriginal people, and particularly Aboriginal people in the NT.

Hepatitis B can lead to severe liver degradation, and liver cancer in some cases if left untreated.

While non-chronic infections can be cured, most NT cases are chronic, and can be treated — though not cured — through regular check-ups to monitor liver function.

Anngie Everitt, a nurse who runs a hepatitis clinic in Darwin, said the main way hepatitis B was transmitted in the NT was from mother to child, during birth.

"It's babies, it's people that either contract from birth, or at a really young age, that are most likely to develop chronic hepatitis B, which requires lifelong treatment," she said.

Anngie Everitt runs a Darwin clinic for all types of hepatitis. (ABC News: Tilda Colling)

Mr Gurruwiwi said often people did not even realise they had the infection until they developed serious liver problems.

"Young people, especially, they don't notice it in their bodies," he said.

"A lot of them … I've seen it, they passed [away]."

The HEP B PAST program includes an app that distributes information about hepatitis B in multiple Indigenous languages. (Supplied)

But health workers say the tide is turning.

According to WHO research, since 2011, the Northern Territory has recorded the biggest decrease in hepatitis B mortality rates of any Australian state or territory.

Menzies School of Health Research Professor Jane Davies runs the HEP B PAST program in the Northern Territory, which has been nationally recognised as leading the nation in hepatitis B reduction.

The success of the HEP B PAST program, pioneered by Jane Davies, has been acknowledged by Australia's national hepatitis B strategy. (ABC News: Pete Garnish)

Having started in 2018, the program visits remote Aboriginal communities to deliver a "one stop liver shop", providing all the care needed for hepatitis B diagnosis and surveillance — like bloods and ultrasounds — in one day.

It also offers an app that translates healthcare information into 11 different Indigenous languages.

"You can imagine being told you have this chronic condition, that you could get liver cancer, that you need care every six months — that can be really scary, [and] that can be even scarier if it's not in your first language," Professor Davies said.

The program provides key hepatitis care, including blood tests, in a single day. (ABC News)

The HEP B PAST program has been recognised at a national level for its groundbreaking work, and has been recommended in national strategies as a successful model that could be rolled out in other jurisdictions to help eradicate hepatitis B in Australia.

Professor Davies said the improvement in the data indicated the Northern Territory had actually closed the gap in hepatitis care.

The HEP B PAST program has partnered with Aboriginal health organisations and traditional owners across the Northern Territory. (Supplied)

"Ten years ago we definitely were not meeting national strategy targets for people being diagnosed, for them being engaged in care and for them being on treatment … [but] very recently we're able to say we're achieving the national strategy targets," she said.

"That means that we have 99 per cent of people diagnosed … and the national target is 80 per cent.

"We have 86 per cent of people engaged in care and the national target is 50 per cent, and we have 24 per cent of people on treatment and the national target is 20 per cent. So we're now, for all of those targets, meeting them."

title: Line dancing emerges from 'shadows' as bootscooting becomes popular
text:
Under the bright lights of a Brisbane country music bar, Chelsea Gillum is guiding a crowd through a night of line dancing.

Her shiny cowgirl boots are leading each step on the stage, a stark contrast to four years ago, when she didn't really know what line dancing was.

It was through a chance encounter that this community became something that would help her during a period of intense loss.

"I lost my mum in 2021, and her best friend took me to Gympie Muster the next year," Ms Gillum said.

" I accidentally bumped into the line-dancing sessions, and I just fell in love with it. "

Loading...

Ms Gillum is one of many turning to line dancing for connection and movement, and social media is helping to drive the popularity of the dance beyond country towns.

"It's always been popular, but been in the shadows," she said.

" But now, all the generations that have been doing it for decades are connecting with the younger people who have seen it on social media. "

The Great Western pub is a popular venue for line dancers. (ABC Capricornia: Freya Jetson)

The Great Western pub in Rockhampton, central Queensland, is usually home to bull riding but, every fortnight, more than 300 people come along to kick up dust with their newly learnt moves.

Organisers say what started as a small gathering two years ago has almost tripled in size.

This large group meets every fortnight in Rockhampton. (ABC Capricornia: Freya Jetson)

Social and mental health benefits

Ms Gillum said the line-dancing community was one where everyone was made to feel welcome.

"It's brought friendships into my life I didn't know I needed, all from different ages and demographics," she said.

" You don't need a partner, everyone's doing the same thing so, even if you come alone, you're part of something bigger. "

Ms Gillum founded her own line dancing business with the aim of replicating the experience she enjoyed in Nashville, in the United States.

"I started at one of Brisbane's country bars for free for seven months because I wanted to show them line dancing was a thing," she said.

A study group has found there are physical and social benefits of line dancing. (Supplied: Gilly's Line Dancing)

CQUniversity lecturer Danielle Le Lagadec was part of a group study, which found there were multiple benefits of taking up the form of dance.

"The physical benefits are the most obvious one," Dr Le Lagadec said.

"The movements increase stamina, balance and strength, but also are a type of rehab after illness.

"The social interaction of these events is also a big factor. It reduces anxiety and depression and supports positive wellbeing through interactions with like-minded people."

Some attendees bring their families along and make a night of it. (ABC Capricornia: Freya Jetson)

Something for everyone

For a group of Rockhampton mums, attending line dancing was a New Year's resolution to try something different.

"We discovered that we could dance and laugh and have fun with each other here at line dancing, it's very relaxed here," said Bec Faria.

"They say when your age goes up, your care factor goes down."

Bec Faria (far left) says her group of friends will be line dancing on their overseas trip. (Supplied: Bec Faria)

Line dancing instructor at the Great Western, Emily Holloway, said the free event was held fortnightly and catered for all abilities.

"It's really great to see so many people coming together and making friends," she said.

"[Instructor] Mahalia Hayman and I didn't know each other before we started line dancing, and we've become really good friends since.

Dance instructor Mahalia Hayman (left) and Emily Holloway lead the line dancing at the Great Western in Rockhampton. (ABC Capricornia: Freya Jetson)

title: This star who 'used to hate' the Storm could lead them to another premiership
text:
Jahrome Hughes has a confession to make: he once was one of those who hated seeing Melbourne win.

Not because he didn't like their players or respect coach Craig Bellamy, he just got sick of watching them succeed when he was a youngster.

"I remember, I actually used to hate the Storm because they were so good," the Storm half admitted this week.

Hughes will on Sunday play his third grand final in six seasons for the Storm, while gunning for a second premiership to go with the ring he won in 2020.

What you need to know about NRL grand final day Photo shows Reece Walsh takes a shot at goal during an NRL game. Kick-off times, pre-game entertainment and all the players taking the field. Here's everything you need to know for grand final day in Sydney.

No club has played in more grand finals in the NRL era, with Melbourne's 12 four clear of the next best, the Sydney Roosters.

Sunday's decider against Brisbane will also mark Craig Bellamy's 11th as coach, taking him past Wayne Bennett for the most in history.

And on joining the Storm in 2017, Hughes immediately saw what made them the winning machine he once envied.

"I've got a lot of respect for Craig and what he's done," Hughes said.

"I know he's a big reason for it, just what he brings to the club, and how hard he works. He demands that from his players, and his staff as well."

Hughes is not alone.

"Because they're so successful, I think it's hard to like the Storm when you're a fan of another team," prop Josh King said.

"I certainly never hated them that much that I was actively cursing them or anything.

"But when you're a young fella and probably don't understand much about footy, it's easy to dislike a team that wins all the time.

"Once I started to play professionally and tried to better myself, that's when the Storm became really intriguing to me."

For others, there were obvious reasons to like the Storm.

Harry Grant says he always had respect for the Storm and its Queensland contingent. (Getty Images: Cameron Spencer)

"I always liked the Storm and respected them from afar, with so many good Queenslanders playing for them," captain Harry Grant said.

"But also just the way they carried themselves and played in games, it was pretty enjoyable and exciting to watch."

In reality, the likes of Hughes are now the ones driving the next generation of Melbourne success, and giving rival fans every reason to look on with envy.

His effort to return 22 days after breaking his forearm to play in a preliminary final will likely go down in folklore, and last year's Dally M Medallist again looms as crucial on Sunday night.

"It was very, very inspiring to see," Grant said.

"The way he sort of attacked that … he played within 22 days but was training for a week before that.

"The best thing was, he went out and did his job to the standard that we know Jahrome can do, and you know, fingers crossed, he can do that again on Sunday."

AAP

title: Accidental treasure hunters want to send ancient Buddha statue 'home'
text:
Two mates who unearthed a centuries-old rare Buddha statue in Western Australia's remote Shark Bay region are calling on Prime Minister Anthony Albanese to diplomatically return the Ming Dynasty figurine "home" to China.

Leon Deschamps and Shayne Thompson want the Buddha repatriated as a symbol of peace and goodwill, and for Shark Bay to be publicly acknowledged as the birthplace of WA's pearling industry.

Leon Deschamps hopes the Baby Buddha can be returned to China, appealing through the prime minister's office. (ABC Midwest and Wheatbelt: Chris Lewis)

Seven years ago, the pair stumbled upon a 15-centimetre bronze Buddha, buried beneath 20cm of topsoil near a roadside.

"When I first lifted the statue from the ground, its weight struck me, and as I turned it over in the late afternoon sun, the worn gold shimmered," Mr Thompson said.

The discovery has seen them spend considerable time and money investigating theories about how the small statue came to rest in the red dirt of the WA's north.

Leon Deschamps says, to his knowledge, no-one has returned to the site where the Baby Buddha was discovered to see what else might lie beneath the sands. (ABC Midwest and Wheatbelt: Chris Lewis)

"However it got here, it was carried by someone who held it sacred and potentially who had it in their family for centuries prior to that," Mr Deschamps said.

" It's four or 500 years old, it's only been buried for the last couple of hundred. "

Shayne Thompson at the 2025 Perth Multicultural Festival. (Supplied: Shayne Thompson)

A seven-year mystery

After finding the Buddha, the pair were convinced it was from a Ming "treasure" ship, large wooden vessels that sailed from China in the 15th century.

Despite their efforts, including engaging a television shipwreck hunter program, the theory has never been proven.

The bronze Buddha has a chocolate-brown patina, with worn gilding that glows gold under sunlight. (Supplied: Shayne Thompson)

Ian MacLeod of the West Australian Museum identified that the Buddha was buried between 100 and 150 years ago, and it was verified as from the Ming Dynasty by Asian art expert Lee Young.

Mr Thompson said Ming Dynasty Buddhas were typically made of gilt bronze using the lost-wax casting method.

"This process involves creating a wax model of the statue, enclosing it in a clay mould, melting the wax to create a cavity, and then pouring molten bronze into the cavity," he said.

From the red sands of Shark Bay, the finders hope Baby Buddha will one day return to its homeland in China. (Supplied: Shayne Thompson)

"After the metal cools, the mould is broken away, and the bronze casting is then finished with gilding, which applies a thin layer of gold to the surface.

"Once a year, on Buddha's birthday, devotees pour water over the statue's shoulders while reciting three mantras: do good deeds, speak good words, and think good thoughts."

Mr Deschamps believed the sands of Shark Bay kept many secrets of the past.

"We're still not sure what lies beneath where we found the Buddha, we'd love to see an archaeological dig at the location," he said.

Pearls of history

The pearling lugger Galli-Cuci (also known as "The Galla"), once used in the pearling industry by Dennis Holt’s father. (Supplied: Dennis Holt)

A more commonly accepted theory is the Buddha belonged to one of the early pearlers in the Shark Bay region.

Once only accessible by ship, Shark Bay was the birthplace of Western Australia's pearling industry in the 1850s, driven by demand for pearl shell to make buttons.

Pearlers used Malay, Chinese and Aboriginal people as labourers, but eventually Chinese-owned pearling operations established their own camps in the region.

Today a popular tourist destination, the town of Denham was once a thriving fishing community. (Supplied: Dennis Holt and ABC Midwest and Wheatbelt: Chris Lewis)

According to the WA Museum, a 1886 census counted 200 people involved in the Shark Bay pearl fishery consisting of 60 Europeans, 102 Chinese and 68 Malays, with the Chinese controlling seven of the 68 vessels in the Bay.

But the population then dwindled later that year, after the government restricted the number of pearling leases Chinese people could buy, leading to a tense stand-off with armed police.

Mr Deschamps said this history should be recognised.

"In Broome, you see the Japanese pearling industry acknowledged and honoured, and it's a massive part of their tourism industry, we want that for Shark Bay," he said.

"So part of what we'd really like to see is a [Chinese] memorial of some description, we'd love to see a Buddhist peace memorial."

Red sands and tidal waters, the locals often refer Shark Bay to where the desert meets the sea. (ABC Midwest and Wheatbelt: Chris Lewis)

An act of diplomacy

Mr Deschamps wants Prime Minister Anthony Albanese to give the infant Buddha statue to Chinese President Xi Jinping to be passed to the Buddhist community in China as a symbol of peace and recognition of history between the countries.

"It's important that this isn't done quietly; we could hand it back tomorrow to a Buddhist organisation in China, and no-one would ever hear about this," he said.

"What's important is having the government acknowledge its importance as a sacred item, and acknowledge the importance of repatriating that item to the people that it belongs to."

Fossicking through the pearling camps

Dennis Hoult has uncovered several historical artefacts, including what appear to be Chinese cash coins, once used up until the 20th century. (ABC Midwest and Wheatbelt: Chris Lewis)

Dennis Hoult has spent his life in the Shark Bay region as a commercial fisher, but his father was the last pearler in Shark Bay, taking over the family business from his father.

Numerous remnants of old pearling camps have been discovered across Shark Bay. (ABC Midwest and Wheatbelt: Chris Lewis)

His great-grandmother was half Malay and half Aboriginal, while his great-grandfather was a Malay man from Broome, drawn to the area to find the area's unique pearls with gold lustre and abundant pearl shell.

Under the Pearling Act, Shark Bay licences were issued by the WA government to regulate and control the industry. (ABC Midwest and Wheatbelt: Chris Lewis)

He remembers his family speaking about the pearling camps scattered across the region, and himself fossicking and finding some trinkets, belt buckles and coins.

"I have a map that we collated together with my uncle before he passed a few years ago, and we've got all the names of all the pearling camps, and there was something like 55," he said.

Dennis Hoult descends from one of Shark Bay's pioneering pearling families. (ABC Midwest and Wheatbelt: Chris Lewis)

Honouring Nick's legacy of peace

Mr Deschamps' quest for public acknowledgement of Chinese pearlers is motivated by his late friend Nick Pedrocchi, who died in 2022.

Malgana man Nick Pedrocchi, who passed in 2022, was a cherished friend to Leon and Shayne. (Supplied: Shayne Thompson)

"On the night that we found the Buddha, we bought it home, and my Malgana friend Nick was there, and his very first response was that the Buddha was sacred, that it wasn't just a valuable item, but it was something that people worshipped," he said.

"The sacred items of his people are in museums all over the world, so he sent us on a journey which has been about getting the Buddha home to the people that find it sacred.

"If we can use the Buddha to bring people together, then I know it would make Nick really happy."

Mr Thompson said finding the right custodians was vital.

"It's important the statue goes to custodians who will connect with it, and Leon and I now feel a bond with Buddhism through this single object," he said.

A sunset over Little Lagoon, Shark Bay, a wild place of beauty and stories still untold. (ABC Midwest and Wheatbelt: Chris Lewis)

A federal government spokesperson said cultural heritage objects had previously been returned to foreign governments voluntarily, including by major cultural institutions.

It is open to the discoverers of the figurine to return it to China voluntarily, the spokesperson said.

title: Classroom remote learning trial to tackle non-attendance, school refusal
text:
For year 11 student Amadeo Ambrosino, a school day can be far from typical.

The 17-year-old lives with cerebral palsy and quadriplegia, and often has appointments during school hours.

But an educational trial, where a robot takes Amadeo's place in class, has transformed his learning.

With the help of his mum, he can use his laptop keypad to move the robot between classrooms, and use its microphone and speakers to talk with his teachers and peers.

Amadeo is writing a musical aria, which he wants to share with this class. (ABC News: Andy Cunningham)

"The robot is amazing for me," Amadeo said.

" I can talk or listen and I can tell the other students about my ideas or news. It can feel like I am connecting with my class. "

The two-way telepresence robot has meant Amadeo can learn from the comfort of his Hobart home, or hospital bed, if needed.

Social isolation overcome

Not-for-profit organisation Missing School has been trialling the robots in schools across the country, with the exception of the Northern Territory, for the past three years.

Since 2022, more than 220 robots have been sent into classrooms.

Using a robot has transformed Amadeo's learning. (ABC News: Ebony ten Broeke)

Missing School co-founder Megan Gilmour said the technology connected vulnerable students — who are unable to be in the classroom due to disability, health or other stressors — with access to teachers, peers and learning.

"We know that close to half of the children in the trial were falling behind academically, so it was a really troubling picture," she said.

"But when we provide this two-way digital connection to the classroom for these kids, we see really significant differences.

"It's just a fact that if you can't get access to school, you can't achieve at school."

Megan Gilmour was awarded the 2025 ACT Australian of the Year for her work with Missing School. (Supplied: Salty Dingo)

'Equitable' access to education

Amadeo's mum, Jane Patel, said the telepresence robot had dismantled barriers to her son's learning.

"The psychological impact of the robot is immeasurable," Ms Patel said.

"It's been an amazing process for him. It's really opened my eyes up for how Amadeo is able to access education in a really meaningful and equitable way.

"School is not an all-day thing for us … and I think it's a very lonely existence to be in the shoes of someone like Amadeo. He has a lot of barriers to learning."

Jane Patel is her son's primary carer. (ABC News: Andy Cunningham)

Rosny College English teacher Emma Mathieson said having Amadeo's robot in class had challenged the way she taught.

"The curriculum is really broad, so we can engage students in their passions. Amadeo's is music, so he's brought that into our classroom," she said.

"It's also enabled the other students to be more accepting and developed empathy and understanding, and for Amadeo, it's brought a sense of belonging as well."

Emma Mathieson says she is very grateful for what Amadeo brings to the class. (ABC News: Ebony ten Broeke)

Every child, every school

While the Missing School program pilot was designed to support the educational and social needs of children absent from school due to serious illness or injury, the trial's success has meant a wider group of students will soon benefit from the remote-education model.

From Monday, the program's reach will expand beyond its current students with a new approach using school-owned technology.

The computer's arrow keys can move the robot forward and backwards and around. They also tilt the camera. (ABC News: Andy Cunningham)

A modified program, Scaling Statewide School Telepresence Solutions to Increase School Attendance — in partnership with the Department of Education, Children and Young People — aims to capture all students unable to attend school.

If your child can't go to school – what can you do? Photo shows A composite of three images, of a young girl in a school uniform, clinging to school gates or lying on steps. There's no easy solution, and every kid's situation is different, but here are some resources that might help.

"The program can work for any student experiencing school isolation. It can be students with school anxiety or school refusal, those in remote areas who can't physically reach a school, even students having a relatively short-term illness or injury," Ms Gilmour said.

"It's so adaptable, so long as there's a connection between the school and the family."

Ms Gilmour said since COVID, the legislation has been in place in Australia to implement the program at scale. What was missing was the policy to enable it.

With a grant from the Tasmanian Community Fund, Tasmania will be the first state to trial the expanded program, with a cluster of 34 schools to take part in the initial 18-month pilot.

Loading...

If successful, Missing School intends to scale up the program to be adopted nationwide using schools' own technology.

"We're talking about screens, tablets and those video conferencing tools that are used ubiquitously now, such as Microsoft Teams and Zoom, to enable students to dial in," Ms Gilmour said.

" We call it 'teach one technology' where teachers are able to teach to students who are coming in virtually while other students are physically present. "

Increasing school attendance

Tasmania, with its poor school attendance rates and low attainment rate, stood to benefit from the virtual learning model.

"We know that 50 per cent of children did not complete year 12 in 2023," Ms Gilmour said.

"We also know that about 50 per cent of children in Tasmania are experiencing chronic school non-attendance.

"One in three students, about 24,000 children in Tasmania, could be experiencing missed school due to a health condition, either a medical condition or a mental health condition."

Amadeo can typically sit in his wheelchair for about 2 hours before feeling uncomfortable. (ABC News: Simon Farrell)

Ms Gilmour said reconnecting with the classroom, importantly, helped students to continue friendships.

"Social connection is one of the primary things enabled," she said.

"This Australian first is a proud moment for Tasmania in its commitment to keeping vulnerable students connected to school. An education system that puts school connection, wellbeing and learning first, will support students wherever they are."

title: From 'snotty nose' to 'yahoos': The language banned from parliament
text:
Have you ever called your colleague a "hairy-nose wombat", a "giggling goose", or yelled "hell yeah" across the office?

If you were a politician and used one of those expressions in parliament, you would've been asked to withdraw your comment.

In Australian politics, words and phrases used in parliament that are seen as insulting, abusive, or a deliberate lie are deemed to be 'unparliamentary language'.

Queensland members of parliament have been called out when referring to each other as "slipperier than an eel in a bucket of snot", "big fat bag of wind", and "the Ned Kelly who occupies the Chair of this Assembly".

Members have been asked to withdraw for using phrases like 'knucklehead' and 'humbug'. (ABC News: Peter Mullins)

The speaker of the House, a member of parliament (MP) who is assigned to oversee the sitting proceedings, decides what language is unparliamentary, and they'll ask the member who said the phrase to withdraw it.

Unparliamentary language can be "difficult to define" and there is "no exhaustive list", as then-acting speaker Jim Fouras explained to the 51st Queensland parliament.

Words and phrases banned from parliament Snotty nose

Drunk as a skunk

Mean girl stance

Guts

Hooligans

"Generally, it is any language or expression that is unworthy of the dignity of the House or parliament as an institution," he told the House in 2005.

Expressions that have been declared unparliamentary over the decades in the state's parliament also include: ranting ratbag, mob of shysters, bushrangers, city slicker, humbug, political loafer, and knucklehead.

No 'bin chicken' noises

University of Queensland research fellow Sam Hames, from the school of languages and cultures, said what is considered unparliamentary is up to the interpretation of the speaker.

He said some of the rulings weren't "necessarily consistent over time" due to different speakers making the calls.

Julian Hill withdrew his comments that likened opposition MPs to the sounds of ibises. (ABC News: Matt Roberts )

In the federal parliament, the term "bin chickens" was ruled to be unparliamentary by Deputy Speaker Maria Vamvakinou in late 2022.

Julian Hill, the federal MP for Bruce, had referred to the opposition as sounding like ibises in the House of Representatives.

"We've heard the blather and the noise from the bin chickens over there," the Labor MP told the House.

Words and phrases banned from parliament Parliamentary delinquent

No. 1 political plagiarist and brain-sucker of the Chamber

Why don't you do it like a man and not like a worm?

Haven't seen a gutter you don't want to get into

Before withdrawing the comment, Mr Hill said it was "a bit unfair to bin chickens".

In this instance, Dr Hames said the speaker saw the term "bin chickens" being used to reflect the noise specific members were making in the House.

"I imagine there would be many other instances in parliament where bin chickens was not considered a reflection of other members, and it was acceptable to say," he said.

The house speaker will call on a member that uses language deemed unparliamentary to withdraw comments. (ABC News: Peter Mullins)

'Happy to drop the c-word'

Sometimes politicians have attempted to be creative with unparliamentary language.

In a debate on the latest budget in 2018, then-Whitsunday MP Jason Costigan declared to the House he was "happy to drop the c-word in here".

Words and phrases banned from parliament He did not have a great deal between the ears

Giggling goose

You're as crooked as a corkscrew

He has been knocked about by a buffalo himself

He followed up by saying "because coal is king" — the combustible rock being the "c-word" the MP was referring to in his speech.

At the end of his contribution to the proposed legislation, then-deputy speaker Joe Kelly cautioned all members that going forward, using the phrase "the c-word" would be considered unparliamentary.

"If you want to refer to coal, refer to it as coal," Mr Kelly told the House.

Certain words and phrases cannot be uttered in the walls of Queensland Parliament House. (ABC News: Brigham Edgar)

'Parliamentary delinquent'

The official transcripts reveal Queensland politicians have been calling each other "fools" since the 1800s.

The ABC looked at the records of debates and procedures, known as the Hansard, from the 19th century to the present day.

Phrases and words can be banned from being used in the chamber if they are considered to be unparliamentary. (ABC News: Peter Mullins)

Here are some phrases from politicians over the decades that were ruled unparliamentary and withdrawn by MPs:

Bugger-all people

Squealed like hell

The hairy-nosed wombat of environment ministers across Australia

Super rat is on his feet

I know he prefers to sit in dark rooms with his little tin foil hat on and draw out his policies

Yahoos

You smell

'That is just how I talk'

Loading...

It is not an excuse to use unparliamentary language because it is just the way you talk, as a Central Queensland MP learned the hard way.

Words and phrases banned from parliament This man trades in death

Rottener than anybody in Queensland

I thought you had just come out of the sewer to deliver your speech

Queens Street clot

She is coming as a jellyfish, because they do not have a spine

Vaughan Johnson, who held the seat for the seat of Gregory in 2014, had used the phrase "like bloody hell!" when debating legislation on livestock offences.

It prompted then-deputy speaker, Verity Barton, to tell Mr Johnson he "may have cussed" during his contribution.

Miss Barton then explained to him that he "may have sworn and used unparliamentary language".

"That is just how I talk all the time, Madam Deputy Speaker," the LNP MP said, before eventually agreeing to withdraw.

Sometimes politicians have attempted to be creative with unparliamentary language. (ABC News: Peter Mullins)

A reflection of society

Dr Hames, along with a team of researchers from UQ, analysed the proceedings of the Australian House of Representatives and Senate from 1901 to early 2024.

During this time, nearly 1.8 million speeches were given by politicians, with the term 'unparliamentary' appearing more than 7,100 times.

He said the language considered unparliamentary had evolved over time reflecting the broader changes in society.

Dr Hames said in the earliest parliament, there was a lot of heavily racialised and derogatory language which was not ruled unparliamentary.

"Whereas today it definitely would be unparliamentary," he said.

title: De Minaur hits career-best mark with win at Shanghai Masters
text:
Alex de Minaur's late-season surge towards again featuring in the end-of-season ATP Finals has continued with the Australian ace enjoying a landmark day as he roared into the last-16 at the Shanghai Masters.

But not for the first time, "Demon" will be the only Aussie left standing in the singles at a Masters 1000 event after his two compatriots, Chris O'Connell and Aleksandar Vukic, both went tumbling out of the tournament.

De Minaur proved far too good for world number 45 Camilo Ugo Carabelli, dispatching the Argentine 6-4, 6-2 in just 88 minutes to annex a personal-best 48th victory of the season.

The victory took him past the mark of 47 wins in the 2024 and 2022 seasons, while his 35th hard-court victory of 2025 is the most on the surface by any player this campaign.

Only Carlos Alcaraz (67) and Taylor Fritz (50) have enjoyed more victories this year than his 48, while de Minaur is also the first Australian man for 21 years, since Lleyton Hewitt, to enjoy that many wins in a single campaign.

He seems to be getting stronger the longer the season progresses, and will fancy his chances of bringing up a half-century this week as he next faces Poland's world number 66 Kamil Majchrzak, a 6-4, 6-0 victor over 29th-seeded American Brandon Nakashima.

De Minaur lost to Italian Jannik Sinner in the China Open semifinals in Beijing earlier this week, his 11th straight loss to the world number two, but the pair can not meet in Shanghai until the final as they are on opposite sides of the draw.

Eventual Beijing champ Sinner made a solid start to his title defence with a straightforward 6-3, 6-3 win over German Daniel Altmaier, setting up a last-16 clash with Dutchman Tallon Griekspoor in the next round.

But life looks easier on de Minaur's half of the draw after Alcaraz pulled out of the tournament with a left ankle concern following his victory in the Japan Open.

The Australian could meet Daniil Medvedev, a 6-1, 6-1 winner over qualifier Dalibor Svrcina on Saturday, should he get past Majchrzak, and that would consolidate his already strong position to get into the ATP Finals in Turin for the second straight year.

He is currently seventh in the season-long "Race to Turin" with only the top eight qualifying, and he has already built a healthy lead over the ninth-placed player, Britain's Jack Draper.

But once again, de Minaur has proved the best of the original half-dozen Australians in the Shanghai main draw after his fellow Sydneysiders both succumbed, O'Connell eliminated by Canada's 23rd seed Denis Shapovalov 6-3, 6-2 and Vukic going down to Portugal's Nuno Borges 7-6 (9/7), 6-4.

AAP

title: South Australian farmers 'on knife edge' ahead of summer after a year of dry conditions
text:
South Australian farmers say they are still feeling the strain of drought after inconsistent winter rains left little room for recovery before the coming summer.

"We're on a knife edge," SA Dairyfarmers' Association president Robert Brokenshire said.

"We are all concerned about what's going to happen late spring/summer.

"If the spring shuts off early and we have a hot, tough, long summer … we'll be in bother bigger than you could believe.

"So again, we're nervous that's it."

The conditions had been brewing in the state for more than a year, according to the Bureau of Meteorology's Daniel Sherwin-Simpson.

"Since the start of last year, we've seen very much long-term rainfall deficiencies, some of them being the highest on record across the agricultural areas of South Australia," he said.

"Those continued well into this year."

In the Adelaide Hills, Callington farmer Jodie Burr said she had spent tens of thousands of dollars on water and fodder for her horses and alpacas.

Jodie Burr is an alpaca farmer in the Adelaide Hills. (ABC News: Ashlin Blieschke )

"This has been the worst year that I've seen," she said.

" I've been living in the country ever since I was about 10 years old, and I've never seen it this bad. "

On the Yorke Peninsula, Maitland farmer Ben Wundersitz said he had experienced his "driest six months on record".

"We basically went for nine months without rain and I think it has an impact on everyone," he said.

Farmer Ben Wundersitz says he's received enough rain to begin drought recovery. (ABC News: Declan Durrant)

"The local town ran out of water. The golf course was dead.

"You did have that concern that it was never going to rain again. All our rainwater storage was empty."

Winter rain brings hope for some

Winter rains offered relief for some parts of the state, but not everyone benefited.

Mr Sherwin-Simpson said while some parts of the Eyre Peninsula received record rainfall in July, parts of the Murraylands and Riverland regions "missed out".

He said while large parts of the state — outside of the Murraylands and Riverland — received near to slightly above-average rainfall through winter, it was not enough to make up for the "rainfall deficiencies".

"It was a step in the right direction, but we've seen things still broad-spectrum remain fairly dry across the state," he said.

In the Yorke Peninsula, Mr Wundersitz said he received just enough rain to start recovery.

Impact of climate change on farming Photo shows Sheep and ram bones on the ground The farming town of Orroroo, in South Australia's mid north, is a microcosm of the drought plaguing swathes of Australia. What is its future in a changing climate?

"Once it sort of rained, we could see hope," he said.

"For us, I suppose the drought has broken. Obviously for many areas in the state that's ongoing."

Mr Wundersitz said it would still be a challenging road to recovery.

"We're in for a couple of tough years," he said.

"I think to bounce back to where we were is quite a few years away."

Mr Brokenshire also believes a full recovery will take time.

"This is a significant drought; I've never seen anything like it before," he said.

"I'm hoping I'm wrong and that it breaks, but at the moment the signals are not strong for a break in the drought.

"Depending on the severity of the drought in each region, it could take three to four years.

" But certainly there wouldn't be one farmer in South Australia that will meet full recovery from this drought in less than two years. "

Entering a 'green drought'

While fields of green have been appearing across the state, Mr Brokenshire said the prolonged periods of dry conditions meant many of South Australia's farms had entered a "green drought".

"[People] driving through Mount Compass over the weekend would think, 'What am I talking about? Look how green and lush it is'," he said.

"Well, that's called a green drought because there's no bulk in that green, there's no fibre in that green, and that is unusual but that's part of the problem we have when we have a drought.

" To the eye it looks great but when you're farming you know it's not anywhere near it where it would be. "

Back in the Adelaide Hills, even with some rain, Ms Burr said she has struggled to grow grass and her fields have been overcome with weeds.

Ms Burr says she has to keep the weeds if she wants to maintain moisture. (ABC News: Ashlin Blieschke)

"There is a lot of green around but if you have a look, it is capeweed — all that yellow flower is capeweed," she said.

Ms Burr said she had no choice but to keep the weeds if she wanted any hope of maintaining moisture in the ground.

Farmers forced to innovate

The challenge of drought has also presented opportunities for innovation, as farmers find new ways to keep producing under the strain of the conditions.

"I think the positive from these dry seasons really has been our ability to grow grain on so little rainfall," Mr Wundersitz said.

"Even as little as 10 years ago we would have basically produced just about nothing, but we just keep edging forward and our productional farming systems just become more and more sustainable."

title: Australia were world champs, now teams are scrambling for players
text:
Players tossed their gloves in the air in celebration as they ran towards a huddle in the middle of the softball field. Australian flags waved in the stands and the team shouted with joy.

With a throw to first base to run the final Canadian batter out, the Australian men's softball team — the Aussie Steelers — were crowned world champions in 2022.

It was just the second time the Steelers had been world champions and appeared to be a sign the sport, a popular inclusion in Australian schools for years, was reaching new heights.

Harry Saisell says many of his friends will miss softball games because they have another sporting match they care more about at the same time. (ABC News: Emily Anderson)

But less than three years after watching his idols take home the trophy, Canberra softballer Harry Saisell is battling to find enough players to fill a team sheet each week.

"People don't want to be seen playing softball," the 16-year-old said.

"It's a hard sport, and it's really fun, but people don't see that."

A once-thriving sport

Softball is a variation of baseball invented in the late 1800s and uses a larger ball and smaller field.

The sport is predominantly played by female participants and will be included in the 2028 Los Angeles Olympic Games as a women's only sport, however, the men's game has a strong presence around the world.

Archive footage of a softball camp from 1961. (ABC News: archives)

But in Australia, players and the sport's peak bodies are concerned softball is no longer able to compete with the popularity of other sports.

It means remaining junior players like Harry regularly play up for older divisions and fill in for multiple teams each season.

"I'm worried to see what will happen in the future — I've lost heaps and heaps of friends to other sports," he said.

"A lot of people in my teams miss out on most games due to basketball grand final, cricket grand finals, [and] baseball."

Since the pandemic, juniors numbers in the ACT have shrunk to the point where the territory's competitions had to be consolidated into one association with just four or five teams in each division.

Of the 23,000 softball members across Australia, there are 1,200 based in the ACT, according to Softball Australia.

There are 23,000 softball players across Australia, according to Softball Australia. (ABC News: Emily Anderson)

No young blood

Softball ACT operations manager Shaun Carroll remembers a time when softball was second to only cricket in its popularity.

"Once upon a time, everyone played softball at school … it was really the only thing around," he said.

"But like everything else, things come and go and there seem to be a lot more things coming for kids to select and go play."

Shaun Carroll says softball used to be second in popularity only to cricket. (ABC News: Mark Moore)

Five years ago, Mr Carroll remembers a vibrant scene of softballers at the long-running Australia Day Carnival in Canberra.

It has not run since 2023 due to a lack of young participants.

"We had hundreds of kids floating around," he said.

" We tried to get it back up off the ground this year, but the interest just isn't there. "

Mr Carroll knows that with fewer young players coming up the ranks, softball competitions could be on their last legs.

Grassroots and junior levels of softball have been struggling to attract the numbers they once did. (ABC News: Emily Anderson)

"I'd love to say that softball's going to be around for 15 or 20 years," he said

"The way it's heading at the moment, it's not looking great.

"But you never know what's around the corner."

Though Mr Carroll admits the Australian Masters Games — which will be hosted in Canberra in October 2025 — tell a different story.

With almost 700 players, softball is the third most popular sport in the biennial competition.

Olympic dreams

State-representative softballer Laura Pardoe first played as a young child and said she was sad to see opportunities to learn softball in school disappear despite it being an Olympic sport.

"The opportunities for those players have just become smaller and smaller, especially for the women and girls," she said.

"This is a sport that's back in the Olympics for 2028, and we're not on that trajectory of opportunities to get to that higher level."

Laura Pardoe is hopeful a big increase in the number of people wanting to play softball is just around the corner. (ABC News: Emily Anderson)

In the 2025 season, the ACT women's competition has just four teams, while the men's grades have seven.

Although the Australian Sports Commission has given an additional $1.96 million to fund high-performance programs for women's softball ahead of the Olympics, this money can not be used at the local level.

Hopes to become 'the next Matildas'

But Softball Australia chief executive Sarah Loh is hopeful Australia's successful bid to host the next Women's Softball World Cup will solve the sport's lack of exposure problem.

"When you're not in schools and you're not on TV, why would a kid want to play softball?" she said.

"This is why our investment into kids is paramount."

Sarah Loh can already see growth in the sport after the World Cup announcement. (ABC News: Glen Mullane)

Ms Loh said the World Cup announcement had already started to create growth within the sport, particularly in Queensland.

"Winning that bid, it's literally changed our fortunes now," she said.

"We have producers putting their hand up saying we want to make you the next Matildas."

The World Cup will be held in Brisbane in April 2027 and is the qualifying event for the 2028 Los Angeles Olympic Games.

title: Financial analysts cast doubt on mega Woodside gas project
text:
Oil and gas giant Woodside's fight to develop the huge Browse offshore gas fields has so far been fought on environmental lines.

Opponents say its proximity to the remote Scott Reef would cause irreparable damage to coral and marine life, and associated carbon emissions were too high in light of recent climate change impact reports.

Opponents of the project gathered in Broome on Friday, amid growing concerns about its impact on Scott Reef. (ABC News: Dunja Karagic)

But some analysts, such as head of energy research at MST Financial, Saul Kavonic, argue Woodside should be more worried about the project's financial viability.

"The cost of the development itself ... leave us with a questionable set of economics for the project," he said.

Big up-front costs

The gas industry has had its eyes on Browse for decades, but past efforts have failed to clear the economic hurdle of drilling for gas in such a remote location.

Woodside needs to build a drilling platform, two floating production facilities and drill around 20 gas wells almost 300 kilometres off WA's Kimberley coast.

To process the gas, it would need to be transported via a 900-kilometre pipeline to the North West Shelf facility in Karratha.

Mr Kavonic said the idea was considered and then abandoned 15 years ago.

"They [also] looked to do the James Price Point development [in the Kimberley], which turned out to be too costly," he said.

"They looked to do floating LNG which turned out to be too risky."

When Woodside abandoned plans to develop Browse as a floating LNG project in 2016, the WA premier at the time said the company was facing engineering costs above $50 billion.

Complicated joint venture

Another hurdle for the project is its complicated corporate structure.

While Woodside is the company the public associates with Browse, the project is a joint venture between several gas players who have agreed to share responsibility for its profits, losses and costs.

Browse joint venture Company Interest (%) Woodside 30.6 BP Developments Australia 44.33 Japan Australia LNG 14.40 PetroChina International Investment 10.67

Mr Kavonic said any of the partners could effectively veto the project if they decided it was not in their interest.

"So you need to herd a lot of cats, a lot of disparate interests, in order to get this over the line," he said.

Optimistic oil price

Mr Kavonic is not the project's only sceptic.

A new report from climate research group Accela Research states many of the assumptions driving Browse's profitability are "fragile".

One of those is the long-term price of oil — the yardstick commonly used when the oil and gas industry plans for the future.

Developing Browse would mean drilling gas wells within 10 kilometres of the remote Scott Reef. (Supplied: Alex Westover)

Woodside is predicting the price of a barrel of oil will hover around $US78 over the next few decades.

But Accela Research financial analyst Axel Dalman said this put the company at odds with others in the industry, including BP, which he said forecast the price would be around $US50 in 2050.

"Whereas other companies think that, perhaps misguidedly, that oil demand will continue to be strong over the next few decades and that will keep prices high," he said.

Mr Dalman said an imminent "glut" in global liquid natural gas (LNG) production, driven by Donald Trump's 'drill baby, drill' agenda, was also likely to bring down prices.

The return of Donald Trump to the White House has sparked a spike in new LNG proposals. (ABC News)

"This new LNG coming out of the US will probably oversupply the market and drive down prices," he said.

"That could be a problem for Browse because obviously the price of LNG is the biggest factor in how profitable the project is because it's going to sell mostly LNG."

But Mr Kavonic cautioned against reading too much into oil price predictions and short-term spikes in LNG supply.

"Browse will probably not be coming online until the early-to-mid-2030s," Mr Kavonic said.

"So that's well after the period of oversupply which some are forecasting between 2027 and 2030."

A Woodside spokesperson said the company did not expect the current LNG supply wave to have a "sustained impact on pricing".

"For example, the International Energy Agency's concerns expressed in both 2009 and 2016 of a sustained LNG glut, with far-reaching impacts on gas prices, did not eventuate," they said.

They said the company was committed to the current Browse to North West Shelf concept.

"[Woodside] remains focused on overcoming key challenges to the delivery of a globally competitive investment proposal."

Browse to Darwin an option

Mr Kavonic said if the Browse to North West Shelf strategy does not work, eyes might turn towards the Ichthys LNG plant in Darwin.

The Inpex LNG plant in Darwin could be a more viable option to process the Browse basin gas than the North West Shelf in Karratha. (ABC News: Dane Hirst)

"The operator of that project has already built a very long pipeline out to the Browse basin to develop their Ichthys fields," he said.

"That gas will start running out in about 10 years and then you could plug Browse into existing infrastructure rather than having to spend the money to build new floating infrastructure and new pipelines."

A date for the final investment decision on the Browse to North West Shelf project has not been set, but is expected by the late 2020s.

title: One of the world's best vocal groups is sharing centuries-old music on their Australian tour
text:
Once upon a time, you could only hear choirs singing angelic music with no instruments in churches.

It was only relatively recently that groups like The Tallis Scholars started bringing this music into concert halls.

The music is reverential, but the experience isn't exclusively religious.

With just a small number of singers, they perform incredibly intricate music with no help from any accompanying instruments to keep them in tune.
